metadata.title: For Your Pleasure // Roxy Music
favouritetracks: In Every Dream Home a Heartache
metadata.pullquote: Glam with a wink and a smile
metadata.summary: Bryan Ferry croons over a variety of instrumental passages (presumably for our pleasure) and the outcome is often akin to a over-theatrical musical. Whether it appeals to you or not, there's no doubt that the overall sound is incredibly distinct in the world of contemporary music
metadata.blurb: The raspy sax, dramatic vocals, and ostentatious instrumentation could just as easily have a place in a gaudy musical as they do on this album.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Ants from Up There // Black Country, New Road
metadata.summary: I wondered how BC, NR would follow up such a creatively charged debut record, and whilst it's not necessarily as ambitious as some had hoped it may be, Ants from Up There has certainly delivered the goods
metadata.blurb: There is so much going on, and the ambitions shown are so bold and brilliant, that you can’t help but root for the record even when it’s falling a little short.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: CRAWLER // IDLES
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by British photographer Tom Ham.
metadata.pullquote: Talbot has the voice of an angel. A tattooed punk angel
metadata.summary: IDLES’ most considered, sonically thoughtful, and complex release to date, and it manages to take the band down a new path without sacrificing what we all already love about them.
metadata.blurb: IDLES’ most considered, sonically thoughtful, and complex release to date, taking the band down a new path while preserving their strengths.

author.name: Rachael Davis, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Hushed and Grim // Mastodon
metadata.pullquote: The metal equivalent of the Penrose steps
metadata.summary: As much fun as its riffs can be, as much as I enjoy the vibrant, crunching tone, and as often as I find myself nodding along to its energetic composition, the album feels like a product of veterans going through the motions. For a really long time.
metadata.blurb: As much fun as its riffs and crunching tone can be, the album feels like a product of veterans going through the motions. For a really long time.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Skin // Joy Crookes
metadata.summary: Joy Crookes has given me another reason to think 2021 is the year of the confident, brilliant debut. Skin has a knack for swaying between intimate, soulful jazz cuts and grander, orchestral pieces, making for a satisfying, moreish sound.
metadata.blurb: Weaving larger-than-life arrangements with razor-sharp yet feather-light lyricism, Crookes sits as the centerpiece of a kind of big band pop.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Friends That Break Your Heart // James Blake
metadata.artworkCredit: was painted in oils by British artist Miles Johnston, who listened to the album as he worked.
metadata.summary: Blake’s vocals are, predictably, beautiful; Blake’s production is, predictably, meticulous; and I, predictably, have lapped it up. But where Assume Form felt like progress, Friends That Break Your Heart feels a little too familiar.
metadata.blurb: Blake’s vocals are, predictably, beautiful; Blake’s production is, predictably, meticulous; and it’s all, predictably, quite predictable.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Pinkerton // Weezer
metadata.artworkCredit: features a ukiyo-e woodcut print called “Night snow at Kambara” by Japanese artist Hiroshige.
metadata.pullquote: Brave and utterly hopeless all at once
metadata.summary: I came for the singalong hooks of “El Scorcho”, “Pink Triangle”, and “Falling for You”, but I stayed for the stories Rivers told about himself - alone in his college dorm, sniffing envelopes sent to him by female fans, his leg held together by pins, fantasising about loves lost and loves unrequited.
metadata.blurb: Come for the singalong hooks of “El Scorcho”, “Pink Triangle”, and “Falling for You”, stay for Rivers Cuomo’s tales of loves lost and loves unrequited.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Rob Wilson

metadata.title: Electric Warrior // T. Rex
metadata.summary: Centrepiece tracks indulge in their fair share of lush string and horn arrangements (and horniness, for that matter) but those moments are tempered by a down and dirtiness worthy of Jimi Hendrix or the Stones. In Marc Bolan the band had a frontman every bit as captivating.
metadata.blurb: Romping rock and roll sounded like a breeze for Marc Bolan, and when you add some vintage Visconti wizardry into the mix, you can’t really go wrong.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Sinner Get Ready // Lingua Ignota
tags: nick cave and the bad seeds
metadata.artworkCredit: features a mask designed by American fashion designer Ashley Rose Couture, with layout by Canadian graphic artist Chimère Noire.
essentialtracks: Man Is Like a Spring Flower
metadata.summary: Inaccessible and a little terrifying from the outset, it isn’t an easy ride, but everything here feels incredibly considered, packed with evocative words and purposeful music.
metadata.blurb: Uncompromising, and very brutal indeed. Some listeners will struggle to see it through to the end, whereas others will feel oddly comforted by its harshness.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Donda // Kanye West
metadata.artworkCredit: features a painting by French-American artist Louise Bourgeois.
metadata.summary: TBD
metadata.blurb: TBD

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Is This It // The Strokes
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by American photographer Colin Lane. It came from a spontaneous photoshoot of Lane’s then girlfriend. “I walked out of the shower and I was completely naked,” she later recalled. “I was walking around the house – he was like, put this glove on. I walked over, boom, that was the shot.”
metadata.summary: The James Dean of indie rock. Cigarette perched on lower lip, bloodshot eyes squinting into the middle distance, the album remains the genre’s poster boy - the impossibly cool standard by which all pretenders must be measured and found wanting.
metadata.blurb: Each note of every individual performance is captured and presented perfectly, with the ragged spirit of the band left intact. It’s scruffy yet masterful.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: CALL ME IF YOU GET LOST // Tyler, the Creator
metadata.album: CALL ME IF YOU GET LOST
essentialtracks: SWEET / I THOUGHT YOU WANTED TO DANCE
metadata.pullquote: Impulsive in all the best ways
metadata.summary: CALL ME IF YOU GET LOST transcends hip-hop. This is a buttery fusion of rap, soul, synth-pop, jazz, and a whole lot more. There’s even a reggae section that doesn’t fall flat on its face.
metadata.blurb: The record transcends hip-hop, a buttery fusion of rap, soul, synth-pop, jazz, and a whole lot more. There’s even a reggae section that hits the spot.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: White Blood Cells // The White Stripes
essentialtracks: I Think I Smell a Rat
metadata.pullquote: Rock music’s answer to an ice-cold six-pack of decentish lager
metadata.summary: The record listens like rock music’s answer to an ice-cold six-pack of decentish lager. What goes on is unrefined, but that only adds to the pleasure of a cheap and cheerful good time.
metadata.blurb: The record listens like rock music’s answer to an ice-cold six-pack of decentish lager. It’s unrefined, but a cheap and cheerful good time.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Blue Weekend // Wolf Alice
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by photographer and director Jordan Hemingway, who filmed 11 videos in seven days with the band ahead of the record’s release.
metadata.pullquote: Bigger, bolder, and gentler than ever
metadata.summary: Ellie Rowsell’s customary drift between spoken-word musings and operatic soarings is alive and well, and the band as a whole is as simpatico as ever - if not moreso. Their gifts are just in service of gentler shapes this time around.
metadata.blurb: Ellie Rowsell’s drift between spoken-word musings and operatic soarings is alive and well, and the band as a whole is as simpatico as ever - if not moreso.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Blue // Joni Mitchell
metadata.pullquote: She’s so good you almost wonder why anyone else bothers
metadata.summary: The early 1970s was a golden era for singer-songwriters, but this stands alongside the very best. The beauty of Mitchell’s songwriting lies in its sheer simplicity. Arrangements are sparse, with often just a lone guitar or piano accompanying the sublime vocal performances.
metadata.blurb: The early 1970s was a golden era for singer-songwriters, but this stands alongside the best. The beauty of Mitchell’s songwriting lies in its simplicity.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Daddy’s Home // St. Vincent
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by American fashion and portrait photographer Zackery Michael, with design by British artist Mishka Westell.
metadata.pullquote: David Bowie and Mia Wallace had a sweet baby girl
metadata.summary: Annie Clark wrangles a myriad of vintage sounds and gives them a stunning contemporary sheen, but it is in service of a world unquestionably her own. David Bowie and Mia Wallace had a sweet baby girl and abandoned her in South Queens.
metadata.blurb: Annie Clark wrangles a myriad of vintage sounds and gives them a stunning contemporary sheen, but it is in service of a world unquestionably her own. David Bowie and Mia Wallace had a sweet baby girl and abandoned her in South Queens.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Bright Green Field // Squid
metadata.summary: The band take characteristics from krautrock, dub, funk, and jazz to form a sound that is remarkably coherent and wholly distinct. It’s chaotic, but it works.
metadata.blurb: Squid take characteristics from krautrock, dub, funk, and jazz to form a sound that is remarkably coherent and wholly distinct. It’s chaotic, but it works.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Fortitude // Gojira
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by frontman Joe Duplantier. Inspired by a 1898 painting of the Greek god Athena by Austrian artist Gustav Klimt, Duplantier ‘wanted to represent an indigenous person, because a lot of the album is a tribute to indigenous communities – I wanted to represent that aspect.’
metadata.summary: Not everything sticks, but I suppose all the great metal albums contain at least a small portion of cheese. I would liken Fortitude to a mild cheddar. Versatile, resilient and, sometimes, unbeatable.
metadata.blurb: All the great metal albums contain at least a small portion of cheese. Fortitude is similar to a mild cheddar. Versatile, resilient and, sometimes, unbeatable.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Never the Right Time // Andy Stott
metadata.summary: Everything unravels at its own pace, with beats gradually mutating under the moody surface. Where others might layer up to obscene degrees, Stott has a knack for finding beauty in minuscule details. It’s practically ambient music for club-goers.
metadata.blurb: Where others might layer up to obscene degrees, Stott has a knack for finding beauty in minuscule details. It’s practically ambient music for club-goers.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: 1 // Drongo
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Frode Holgersen. Each animal represents one of the tracks.
metadata.summary: The band’s tightness gives tracks license to be fluid and adventurous, zipping between genres without ever feeling the slightest bit disjointed. The record delivers on the promise of its artwork, taking listeners on a spectacular musical safari.
metadata.blurb: The record takes listeners on a spectacular musical safari, zipping between genres without ever feeling the slightest bit disjointed.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: G_d's Pee AT STATE'S END! // Godspeed You! Black Emperor
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American illustrator William Schmiechen.
favouritetracks: OUR SIDE HAS TO WIN (for D.H.)
metadata.pullquote: A relentless and marvellous extra slice of Godspeed’s magic.
metadata.summary: Another commanding and deft iteration of Godspeed’s loved and lauded style. Another dose of structured white noise, simple melodies that bely the depth of the composition, erratic arrangements that fizz past just as you grasp what’s going on, and the sum total space to think.
metadata.blurb: Another commanding and deft iteration of Godspeed’s lauded post-rock style. Although lacking the range of previous records, it still offers space to think.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Is 4 Lovers // Death from Above 1979
metadata.artworkCredit: features of photograph of band member Sebastian Grainger’s great uncle and aunt. The former passed away in 2011, and the latter while the album was being recorded. When Grainger went to Chicago to get their affairs in order he came across their old love letters and photos, one of which he thought was ideal for the cover. ‘To me, it’s a perfect metaphor for real love, which is complicated and askew.’
metadata.summary: Produced like a dance record, with endless amounts of saturation and compression applied to, well, everything. This results in no dynamics and no substantial subtleties. If it were any longer than 30 minutes, I’m almost certain it would give me a headache.
metadata.blurb: A rock record produced like a dance record, with endless amounts of saturation and compression applied to, well, everything. This is a failed experiment.

author.name: André Dack, Gabriel Sutton & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Sax on the Beach // Bleeding Gums Murphy
favouritetracks: I Never Had an Italian Suit Blues
Steve Allen’s Naked Happiness (ft. Steve Allen)
Love on the Rocks with a Twist
metadata.pullquote: Few records are better at making you feel worse
metadata.summary: Bleeding Gums’ hard life is laid bare. From brotherly estrangement to Fabergéal financial ruin to dental calamity, the soulful howling and gravelly tone is magnificient.
metadata.blurb: From brotherly estrangement to Fabergéal financial ruin to dental calamity, Bleeding Gums’ soulful howling and gravelly tone is magnificient.

author.name: Michael Clark, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Chemtrails Over the Country Club // Lana Del Rey
favouritetracks: Let Me Love You Like a Woman
metadata.pullquote: Del Rey’s brand of dream pop has never felt more soothing
metadata.summary: Vintage Del Rey (in both senses of the word), though the curious thing about the record is that it flies highest when she sounds least like herself. The songs flicker between sepia and technicolor, giving a tantalising sense of where she might go next.
metadata.blurb: Vintage Del Rey (in both senses of the word), though the curious thing about the record is that it flies highest when she sounds least like herself.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Songs of Love and Hate // Leonard Cohen
tags: nick cave and the bad seeds
metadata.pullquote: A joy. A sad, bitter, solemn, rueful, depressing, hopeless joy.
metadata.summary: The album embraces a brutal honesty that, although daunting on the surface, reminds you that bleakness can be beautiful. It exudes the kind of wisdom that only comes from authentic human experience.
metadata.blurb: An epic poem in LP form, throughout Cohen embraces a brutal honesty that, although daunting on the surface, reminds you that bleakness can be beautiful.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: When You See Yourself // Kings of Leon
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by creative agency Night After Night, a longtime collaborator of the band.
metadata.summary: I’m all for a band’s progression after two decades of making music, but this neither advances Kings of Leon’s sound nor recaptures the glory of their past. It’s stuck in the space inbetween.
metadata.blurb: An album caught in no-man’s land, its dozy stadium rock tunes neither advancing Kings of Leon’s sound nor recapturing the glory of their past.

author.name: Gabriel Sutton, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Little Oblivions // Julien Baker
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Seattle-based oil painter Wylee Risso.
metadata.summary: Whilst I welcome the shift away from skeletal guitars, I don’t think Baker’s strengths lie in creating expansive arrangements herself. These songs sound like they’ve been developed for arenas, which in itself is a strange paradox.
metadata.blurb: The shift away from skeletal guitars is welcome, but Baker’s strength does not lie in expansive arrangements. The songs sound like they’ve been developed for arenas, which is a strange paradox.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: As the Love Continues // Mogwai
metadata.artworkCredit: is the work of graphic designer DLT.
favouritetracks: It's What I Want To Do, Mum
metadata.pullquote: More impulsive than anything we’ve heard from Mogwai before
metadata.summary: An expansive, impressive listen with some delicious moments of climactic eruption. For Mogwai fans, this should feel like a hit in the band’s discography, and for the rest, this is still worth a listen.
metadata.blurb: An expansive, impressive listen with delicious moments of climactic eruption. For Mogwai fans, this should feel like a hit in the band’s discography.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Glowing in the Dark // Django Django
metadata.artworkCredit: features a painting gifted to the band’s drummer and producer, David Maclean, by an old art school friend. Maclean found the painting gathering dust in his parents’ attic and thought its imagery was just the right fit for the record.
metadata.summary: Covered in so much haze that, despite some serious musical detours, tracks still tend to blend together. This is very much the selling point for many listeners, though, and there’s no knocking the aesthetic. I myself have grown enamoured with a handful of tracks.
metadata.blurb: The album dusky psychedelic pop is covered in so much haze that, despite serious musical detours, tracks tend to blend together. It’s a good blend, though.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: For the first time // Black Country, New Road
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph taken by Asaf R.
metadata.pullquote: Leading the way towards a new era of British guitar music
metadata.summary: A debut record that shows what rock music can sound like in the 2020s. Obviously, violins and saxophones have occupied the same space as fuzzy guitars before now, but the ways in which the band use those instruments together can be exhilarating.
metadata.blurb: A blend of teenage angst and a primordial, animalistic sense of something lurking beneath a thin surface, a beastly shape clawing at the other side.

author.name: André Dack, Marcus Lawrence & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Tago Mago // Can
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Ulrich Eichberger.
metadata.summary: Like a house party, it invites you in with a chilled groove and warm atmosphere. Midway through, someone pulls out something a little stronger, all hell breaks loose, time disappears, and the next moment you’re dazed, confused and nursing a warm drink before being promptly turfed out.
metadata.blurb: The record listens like an all-night jam at an impossibly cool bohemian gettogether. It’s funky, relaxed, audacious, exhausting... but above all, it’s brilliant.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Isles // Bicep
metadata.artworkCredit: was the work of Degrau, a design studio founded by Ana Areias, João Castro, Raquel Rei, and Tiago Campeã. Degrau provided a collection of visuals for the release, including singles artwork and live performance interactive pieces.
metadata.pullquote: Bicep-lite rather than Bicep at home
metadata.summary: Tracks swirl about at a slower pace than in Bicep’s debut, and it often feels as though in creating a ‘home version’ of their music they have instead cut out the excitement.
metadata.blurb: Tracks swirl about at a slower pace than in Bicep’s debut. It often feels as though in creating a ‘home version’ they have instead cut out the excitement.

author.name: Marcus Lawrence, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Painting the Roses // Midnight Sister
metadata.pullquote: Part dramatic dream, part sun-soaked soliloquy
metadata.summary: An eclectic mixture of indie rock and baroque pop, with not-so-subtle nods to psychedelia, jazz, dance, and classical music. Not every experiment pays off, but there’s bound to be something for everyone to enjoy.
metadata.blurb: Part dramatic dream, part sun-soaked soliloquy, part love letter to mid-century pop rock, Midnight Sister have sewn together a wistful, woozy record.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: MM..FOOD // MF DOOM
metadata.artworkCredit: was painted by American artist Jason Jägel, who also did the “Hoe Cakes” single cover.
metadata.summary: Everything about MM..FOOD feels effortless. MF DOOM doesn’t try too hard - in fact it feels like he’s barely trying at all. It’s pure, natural talent that cannot be taught, nor replicated. He defies the expectations of wordplay time and time again.
metadata.blurb: Never does the record come off as grandiose or self-important; it’s just that good, and it’s just that much fun. Not a masterpiece, but a master at work.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Great Dismal // Nothing
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American director Jordan Hemingway.
metadata.summary: Unabashedly grim, but reassuringly gentle. The album's striking cover art, of a red-eyed, mud-caked old man with a menacing but fragile look to him, is a pretty good indicator of what I found here.
metadata.blurb: Unabashedly grim, but reassuringly gentle. The album's striking cover art of a menacing but fragile old man is a good indicator of what to expect.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Visions of Bodies Being Burned // clipping.
metadata.summary: A relentless and unpredictable work that feels like the spawn of a Satanic ritual in a theme park. It’s oppressive and challenging, but also warm and charming.
metadata.blurb: Relentless and unpredictable, the album's like the spawn of a Satanic ritual in a theme park. It’s oppressive and challenging, but also warm and charming.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Pet Sounds // The Beach Boys
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph of the band taken by George Jerman at San Diego Zoo. The band members weren't exactly well behaved during the shoot and were banned for life as a result. The typeface used is Cooper Black.
favouritetracks: Let’s Go Away for a While
metadata.pullquote: One big lovey dovey hooby dooby yeah yeah yeah jingle
metadata.summary: The harmonies are wonderful, the instrumentation is charming, and, well, everything sounds rather bloody marvellous. There’s a lot to love and little to dislike. Is it as extraordinary as so often cited? Perhaps not.
metadata.blurb: The harmonies are wonderful, the instrumentation is charming, and, well, everything sounds rather bloody marvellous. Lots to love and little to dislike.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Ultra Mono // IDLES
metadata.artworkCredit: was painted by British artist Russell Oliver, with the concept coming from band frontman Joe Talbot. Oliver recalled that it ‘relates to Joe and the band’s ideal of unconditional love and acceptance for all, including their critics, or political opposition, or for other bands who may have positioned themselves as “rivals” or adversarial. The large pink ball (Joe’s favourite colour) represents this unstoppable and unavoidable ideal of love and acceptance colliding forcefully with such an opponent.’
metadata.pullquote: A brick through the window of Bullshit Inc
metadata.summary: There is a huge amount of musical and lyrical ingenuity to enjoy here, with strong messages and jovial piss takes. One thing is for certain, Joe Talbot is the town crier, a megaphoned voice of a generation.
metadata.blurb: There is a huge amount of musical and lyrical ingenuity to enjoy here, with strong messages, jovial piss takes, and Joe Talbot as the megaphoned town crier.

author.name: Gabriel Sutton, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Universal Want // Doves
metadata.summary: The textures, vocals, and mixing are tediously uniform, and the instrumentation is too often basic in conceit and effects-laden in execution. There’s nothing to grab onto, nothing to shake the feeling that I’m listening to the soundtrack of a cul de sac dinner party.
metadata.blurb: It seems that a template was drawn up and filled in ten times over, such that every track sounds like the last, only wearing a different hat.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Nothing as the Ideal // All Them Witches
metadata.summary: A sumptuously produced blend of folk, rock, post-rock, and psychedelia, all with a smokey stoner sheen. When it gets rolling the grooves are irresistible.
metadata.blurb: A sumptuously produced blend of folk, post-rock, and psychedelia, all with a smokey stoner sheen. When it gets rolling the grooves are irresistible.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Gabriel Sutton

metadata.title: Inner Song // Kelly Lee Owens
metadata.summary: In a way the album is so delicate, so finely made, that it at times feels too fragile for its own good. It’s like a frozen wildflower - intricate and beautiful, but prone to shatter at any moment.
metadata.blurb: The album is so delicate that it feels too fragile for its own good. It’s like a frozen wildflower - beautiful, but could shatter at any moment.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: King’s Disease // Nas
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Afro-Cuban artist Harmonia Rosales. ‘I wanted to incorporate the entire lifecycle just like a king would a leader,’ she said. ‘It goes from birth to innocence and the pearls, and then it’s to the knowledge, which is the snake, and then death, which is why you have the skull at the bottom.’
metadata.summary: Nas frames himself, thematically, as an old king of hip hop, surveying the state of the world, reflecting on his reign, looking forward to the next generation, and speaking as though he’s ready to step aside.
metadata.blurb: A pleasant, consistent, and enjoyable listen. Here’s hoping Nas and Hit Boy build on their clear chemistry with a follow-up.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Fresh Fruit for Rotting Vegetables // Dead Kennedys
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph from the White Night Riots of May 21st, 1979. The riots were in response to the lenient sentence received by Dan White for murdering San Francisco Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk. The typeface used is Engravers’ Old English by Morris Fuller Benton.
metadata.summary: Hardcore punk doesn't come much better than Fresh Fruit for Rotting Vegetables. Dead Kennedys' iconic debut still boasts some of the most brilliant and uncompromisingly cynical songs the genre has ever seen.
metadata.blurb: Dead Kennedys' iconic debut still boasts some of the most brilliant and uncompromisingly cynical songs that punk has ever seen.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Dreamland // Glass Animals
metadata.summary: Dreamland is millennial nostalgia in a nutshell. Dave Bayley yearns for his youth. Enter: Pokemon; G.I. Joe; Scooby Doo; Nintendo 64; Grand Theft Auto; Doom...
metadata.blurb: The album is a nostalgia trip and, unintentionally(?), the longest ‘only Millenials will remember’ meme in some time.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: After the Gold Rush // Neil Young
metadata.artworkCredit: features a solarised photograph of Young walking past the New York University School of Law. It was taken by American photographer Joel Bernstein, who at the time was just 18 years old.
essentialtracks: Don't Let It Bring You Down
metadata.summary: One of the definitive albums released by, quite possibly, the greatest singer-songwriter we've ever seen. To those looking to probe Young's daunting discography: start here.
metadata.blurb: Along with a supremely confident and symbiotic backing band, Neil Young imbues each track with this and easygoing courageousness. A true classic.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Lianne La Havas // Lianne La Havas
metadata.pullquote: One step forward, two steps back
metadata.summary: The record lacks hooks and memorable moments. Lianne La Havas is her most cohesive album to date, but perhaps her most forgettable. It feels like one step forward, two steps back.
metadata.blurb: The record lacks hooks and memorable moments. Although this is La Havas' most cohesive album to date, it may also be her most forgettable.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Parachutes // Coldplay
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph of a globe taken by the band with a disposable Kodak camera. They supposedly bought the globe from WHSmith for ten quid.
metadata.summary: Parachutes is a big ol’ dose of feeling. Chris Martin coos over a warm, shiny, radio-friendly mix with that patented Chris Martin timbre and life suddenly seems quite pleasant, in a drifting, vacant sort of way.
metadata.blurb: Parachutes is nice-feeling music written by nice-seeming blokes. As is the case with all things Coldplay, it’s easy to mock, but it’s easy to like as well.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Mordechai // Khruangbin
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by band bassist Laura Lee together with artist Nathaniel Utesch.
metadata.summary: Mordechai is ultimate festival music. Relaxing yet affecting, these songs are begging to be listened to with a chilled beverage in hand, alongside friends, watching the sun go down.
metadata.blurb: Relaxing yet affecting, these songs are begging to be listened to with a chilled beverage in hand, alongside friends, watching the sun go down.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Rough and Rowdy Ways // Bob Dylan
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph by British photojournalist Ian Berry. It was taken in 1964 at an underground club on Cable Street in east London, which Berry left when people started throwing beer bottles at him. ‘It’s something that happens a lot to photographers in different parts of the world,’ he said, ‘but I think it’s the only time it happened in England to me.’
metadata.summary: Grizzled and dusty, the album is as world-weary as it is worldly. Grandpa Dylan sits in his rocking chair by the fire and regales with old stories between stints of napping.
metadata.blurb: Grizzled and dusty, the album is as world-weary as it is worldly. Dylan sits in his chair by the fire and regales with stories, between naps.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Charlie Clissitt

metadata.title: To Love Is to Live // Jehnny Beth
metadata.summary: The album is purposefully provocative, and whilst this brings exhilarating and hard-hitting moments, it can also result in disorientating frenzies. It feels messy, basically, though this isn't always a bad thing.
metadata.blurb: The album is purposefully provocative, and whilst this brings exhilarating and hard-hitting moments, it can also result in disorientating frenzies.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: RTJ4 // Run the Jewels
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by photographer and filmmaker Tim Saccenti.
metadata.summary: El-P and Mike may have been fighting for the cause before, but now they're on the frontline. On RTJ4, the duo stand up to be counted for what they really are: rappers, producers, activists, husbands, citizens.
metadata.blurb: El-P and Mike are on the frontline now. Here the duo stand up to be counted for what they really are: rappers, producers, activists, husbands, citizens.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Moon & Antarctica // Modest Mouse
metadata.summary: Provided you're in the right mood, The Moon & Antarctica is one of the standout indie rock releases of the 2000s. A volatile relief for all the potential nihilists out there.
metadata.blurb: Provided you're in the right mood, The Moon & Antarctica is one of the standout indie rock releases of the 2000s.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Rob Wilson

metadata.title: Græ // Moses Sumney
metadata.summary: Emotionally vulnerable and creatively restless. The record plays out like a prolonged stream of consciousness, yet every aspect seems carefully constructed. The attention to detail is remarkable.
metadata.blurb: Emotionally vulnerable and creatively restless. The record plays out like a prolonged stream of consciousness, yet every aspect seems carefully constructed.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Man-Machine // Kraftwerk
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Karl Klefisch. Versions of the cover featuring the band used photography by Günther Fröhling.
metadata.summary: The album makes for hypnotic listening, bobbling along like a well-mannered German robot. All these years later it still sounds like the future.
metadata.blurb: The album makes for hypnotic listening, bobbling along like a well-mannered German robot. All these years later it still sounds like the future.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Cosmogramma // Flying Lotus
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American actor, author, and artist Leigh McCloskey. The illustration is from a codex McCloskey started in the 1980s. ‘We are part of something vast and wondrous and we are part of something intimate,’ he said. ‘That’s the feeling I got with the album itself. I felt like I was holding something both modern and ancient.’
metadata.summary: Cosmogramma transcends genre, and unless someone, somehow, finds a term that incorporates elements of electronica, jazz, hip-hop, drum and bass, chiptune, IDM and countless other musical forms, it will continue to stand as its own entity.
metadata.blurb: Cosmogramma is a stunning showcase of music made, or at the very least assisted by, computers. Time has only proved it to be a genuine modern masterpiece.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Michael Clark

metadata.title: The Sophtware Slump // Grandaddy
essentialtracks: He’s Simple, He’s Dumb, He’s The Pilot
favouritetracks: So You’ll Aim Toward the Sky
metadata.summary: Despite extended musical passages and eccentric lyrics, the album is remarkably accessible. It's pop music for art students.
metadata.blurb: Despite extended musical passages and eccentric lyrics, The Sophtware Slump is remarkably accessible. It's pop music for art students.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Earth // EOB
metadata.pullquote: An album by a guitarist from Radiohead
metadata.summary: Solo material from a band as prolific as Radiohead can go one of two ways, and for EOB it contributes towards the impression that the band is greater than the sum of its parts.
metadata.blurb: Solo material from a band as prolific as Radiohead can go one of two ways. Here it leaves the impression the band is greater than the sum of its parts.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Song for Our Daughter // Laura Marling
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by Canadian artist Justin Tyler Close.
metadata.summary: Robed in ever so tasteful shades of pinkish beige, bluish beige, and beige, the album is an often sublime Marling masterclass.
metadata.blurb: Robed in ever so tasteful shades of pinkish beige, bluish beige, and beige, Song for Our Daughter is an often sublime Marling masterclass.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: It Is What It Is // Thundercat
metadata.summary: Thundercat rides the album like a surfer hanging ten on the world’s smallest, smoothest, slowest wave. It’s drifting with style; a good time but not terribly eventful.
metadata.blurb: Thundercat rides the album like a surfer hanging ten on the world’s smallest, smoothest, slowest wave. It’s drifting with style, an uneventful good time.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Saint Cloud // Waxahatchee
metadata.summary: Crutchfield’s delicate vocals come through with majestic force. To witness these songs being played live in a chapel would be quite the experience. Someone should work on that.
metadata.blurb: Country music with a modern edge. To witness these songs being played live in a chapel would be quite the experience. Someone should work on that.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Meet The Be Sharps // The Be Sharps
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American artist Andy Warhol. He died shortly after, saying he had ‘nothing left to live for.’
metadata.summary: Some of the richest and most melodious harmonisations of four men since John, Mark, Luke, and Matthew collaborated on their bestselling project some 2,000 years ago.
metadata.blurb: The richest and most melodious harmonisations of four men since John, Mark, Luke, and Matthew collaborated on their bestselling project 2,000 years ago.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien, Andrew Bridge & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Uneasy Laughter // Moaning
metadata.summary: It all winds up feeling a bit clean cut, a bit airbrushed. The album’s a perfectly pleasant smorgasbord of gothy synth pop which goes in one ear and out the other.
metadata.blurb: The album's all a bit clean cut, a perfectly pleasant smorgasbord of gothy synth pop which goes in one ear and out the other.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: A Written Testimony // Jay Electronica
metadata.summary: The sampling is seriously inventive and a joy to behold, the production is consistently phenomenal, and the thoughtful lyrical content rewards further listens.
metadata.blurb: A distinctive project that showcases exactly what Jay Electronica is all about. With a little help from a friend, of course.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Plastic Beach // Gorillaz
metadata.artworkCredit: features a four meters high model made by Asylum Models & Effects Ltd based on illustrations by group co-founder Jamie Hewlett.
metadata.summary: Plastic Beach’s finest moments sound, appropriately, like synthetic luxury. It’s buoyant and aspirational, feeling like a release of tension after the comparative harshness of Demon Days.
metadata.blurb: Classic Gorillaz. Buoyant and aspirational, the project feels like a release of tension after the comparative harshness of Demon Days.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: To Bring You My Love // PJ Harvey
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Martin Callomon, who was the Island Records art director at the time of the album's release.
metadata.summary: With PJ Harvey it feels like you’ve stumbled across the ad hoc performance of a travelling mystic. It’s black magic with a smile. There’s blood trickling from the corner of its mouth, but then who are we to judge?
metadata.blurb: With Harvey it feels like you’ve stumbled across the ad hoc performance of a travelling mystic. It’s black magic with a smile.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: The Slow Rush // Tame Impala
metadata.summary: Dreamy psychedelia takes centre stage, with very little shift in pace or tone. I'm hugely enamoured with the first handful of tracks, but gradually become numb to the music's whimsical nature.
metadata.blurb: Kevin Parker’s latest project has all the hallmarks of what came before, and it pushes harder on his more avant garde sensibilities.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Unknown Pleasures // Joy Division
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by English graphic designer Peter Saville, Factory Record’s creative director at the time. The band presented him with a page from the Cambridge Encyclopedia of Astronomy, on which was a stacked plot of radio emissions from the pulsar star CP 1919. Saville inverted the colours, and the rest is legend.
metadata.summary: Pretty much everything about Unknown Pleasures was, and continues to be, a total fucking triumph in cathartic misery. It’s reassuring that a record so emotionally detached and theatrically passionate can still inspire music listeners in 2020.
metadata.blurb: Pretty much everything about Unknown Pleasures was, and continues to be, a total triumph in cathartic misery. It’s a true classic.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Be Up A Hello // Squarepusher
metadata.summary: This is a veteran of electronic music who has nothing else to prove. The album isn't a game changer; instead a proud statement, delivered with finesse and flair by one of the true masters of IDM.
metadata.blurb: This isn't a game changer; instead a proud statement, delivered with finesse and flair by one of the true masters of IDM.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: There Is No Year // Algiers
metadata.summary: Following 2017’s brutally beautiful Underside of Power, There is No Year feels light in comparison, and even slightly unfinished. A record full to the brim, bursting with potential for something greater than what it ultimately settles for.
metadata.blurb: Throughout much of its run-time, There is No Year seems content revelling in its own (admittedly awe-inspiring) ambience.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Paranoid // Black Sabbath
metadata.summary: As far as straight up heavy metal goes, I think Black Sabbath's Paranoid is one of the very best. It's very sincere and reliably silly. And when it rocks, it fucking rocks.
metadata.blurb: As far as straight up heavy metal goes, Black Sabbath's Paranoid is one of the very best. It's very sincere and reliably silly.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: MAGDALENE // FKA twigs
tags: nick cave and the bad seeds
metadata.artworkCredit: was a collaboration between twigs and English artist Matthew Stone. The effect was achieved by painting onto a 3D scan of twigs. ‘I’m trying to depict bodies that feel real and unreal at the same time,’ Stone said, ‘trying to create something that feels authentically human, but kind of trapping myself within this digital world.’
metadata.summary: MAGDALENE strives for an understated pop epic, yet this is a curious contradiction in itself. For all its instances of greatness and undeniable beauty, the record gets tangled in its own aspirations.
metadata.blurb: For all its instances of greatness and undeniable beauty, MAGDALENE gets tangled in its own pop epic aspirations.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Let England Shake // PJ Harvey
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by English writer and artist Michelle Henning.
metadata.summary: Let England Shake sounds impeccable on all fronts. It is, quite simply, one of the greatest anti-war albums of all time. In this current political climate, its significance has only ascended.
metadata.blurb: Quite simply one of the greatest anti-war albums of all time. In this current political climate its significance has only increased.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Vols. 11 & 12 // Desert Sessions
metadata.summary: The Desert Sessions project has always been a lot of fun. It's sincere music created in the moment by a bunch of talented artists. Returning from an absence of 16 (!!!) years, I'm pleased to report nothing has really changed on that front.
metadata.blurb: The Desert Sessions project has always been a lot of fun. Returning from an absence of 16 (!!!) years, nothing has really changed on that front.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: There Existed an Addiction to Blood // clipping.
metadata.album: There Existed an Addiction to Blood
metadata.summary: A consistent string of exciting, chilling, and innovative experimental hip hop tracks devoid of cheese or pretence. The album is enthralling in the same way that I imagine a vampire's glamouring might be: warm, cold, hypnotic, enticing, and foreboding as all Hell.
metadata.blurb: The album is enthralling in the same way a vampire's glamouring might be: warm, cold, hypnotic, enticing, and foreboding as all Hell.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Sonic Citadel // Lightning Bolt
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by the band’s drummer, Brian Chippendale.
metadata.summary: I have it on good authority that this duo is formed of stellar talent, and by all accounts their live performances burst with energy. But Sonic Citadel sticks around for too long on the same idea for the effect to carry over here.
metadata.blurb: Sonic Citadel leans into the grubby, raw, jam-like nature of the duo’s live performances, records it, and calls it a day. It’s like a whirring motorcycle.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Ghosteen // Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds
tags: nick cave and the bad seeds
metadata.artworkCredit: features an adapted painting by artist Tom duBois. The original, Breath of Life, depicts Adam the Garden of Eden. The Nick Cave edition replaces Adam with a lamb and a white horse.
metadata.summary: The aura of each composition is beautiful, yet there’s also the aching feeling of something missing. Ghosteen is quite stunning as an overall entitity. However, without specific songs standing out, it’s surprisingly forgettable.
metadata.blurb: The aura of each composition is beautiful, yet there’s also the aching feeling of something missing. Stunning, and yet also oddly forgettable.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Pretty Hate Machine // Nine Inch Nails
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American artist Gary Talpas. The remaster included a new cover designed by American graphic artist Rob Sheridan.
metadata.summary: Nine Inch Nails rapidly became renowned for emotive and affecting music. Pretty Hate Machine contains all of these qualities, albeit in anxious tidbits.
metadata.blurb: Nine Inch Nails rapidly became renowned for emotive and affecting music. Pretty Hate Machine contains those qualities, albeit in anxious tidbits.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Abbey Road // The Beatles
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by English art director John Kosh and features a photograph taken by Iain Macmillan. Inspired by a Paul McCartney sketch, the shot was one of six from a ten-minute window in which Macmillan balanced on a stepladder in the middle of Abbey Road while a policeman held up traffic behind him.
metadata.summary: The last word of a band with nothing left to prove, and it sounds like it. Exceptional without being seminal, the record is not a high watermark, but then it didn’t need to be.
metadata.blurb: The last word of a band with nothing left to prove, and it sounds like it. Exceptional without being seminal, but with some truly classic songs.

author.name: Gabriel Sutton, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: All My Heroes Are Cornballs // JPEGMAFIA
metadata.summary: There's a glaring sense of lunacy throughout. It's as though JPEGMAFIA is snapping between multiple identities. I actually find the madness quite soothing, though I'm not really sure how or why.
metadata.blurb: There's a glaring sense of lunacy throughout. It's as though JPEGMAFIA is snapping between multiple identities, and yet still manages to be soothing.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Lost Girls // Bat for Lashes
metadata.summary: Lost Girls stands firm as a satisfying-yet-unspectacular entry in the Bat for Lashes discography. It’s practically impossible not to recommend it to those who share Khan’s affection for the ’80s.
metadata.blurb: A satisfying-yet-unspectacular entry in the Bat for Lashes discography. Heartily recommended to those who share Khan’s affection for the ’80s.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Fear Inoculum // Tool
metadata.summary: While I can appreciate a slow build, a rolling riff, and an expansive soundscape, I don't feel like that's what I'm getting here. For the most part, I find boredom and frustration during the 90-minute playtime.
metadata.blurb: While we can all appreciate a slow build, a rolling riff, and an expansive soundscape, TOOL's 90-minute non-epic leaves much to be desired.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Lover // Taylor Swift
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph by Colombian artist Valheria Rocha. Specialising in fashion portraits and collage art, Rocha’s work is ‘inspired by distinctive color palettes, theatricality, and a love for all things vintage and eclectic.’ An apt fit for Taytay, to be sure.
metadata.summary: Hip, catchy… all that stuff. Lover isn’t as expansive as Kate Bush or as daring as St. Vincent, but it is accessible and intelligent, which I think are the hallmarks of Swift at her best.
metadata.blurb: Lover isn’t as expansive as Kate Bush or as daring as St. Vincent, but it is accessible and intelligent, which are the hallmarks of Swift at her best.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Animated Violence Mild // Blanck Mass
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by London-based design and creative studio Middle Boop. It features photography by Alex de Mora with art direction and hand provided by Lucie Red. As in it’s her hand, she didn’t procure a hand.
metadata.summary: It’s like Blanck Mass put Marilyn Manson, Nine Inch Nails, Mario, and the blood of a sacrificial lamb into a kind of sonic blender.
metadata.blurb: It’s like Blanck Mass put Marilyn Manson, Nine Inch Nails, Mario, and the blood of a sacrificial lamb into a kind of sonic blender.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Adventures Of A Reluctant Superhero // Chali 2na & Krafty Kuts
metadata.summary: AOARS is an okay take on playful, skit-heavy hip-hop, but it has some low points, and these are aggravated by a pretty corny superhero conceit.
metadata.blurb: Krafty Kuts and Chali 2na seem to lack conviction on this album, never attempting anything overly exciting, content with being serviceable.

author.name: Kieran James, Marcus Lawrence & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Elvis Presley // Elvis Presley
metadata.artworkCredit: uses a photograph taken by William V. “Red” Robertson of Robertson & Fresch. It captures Presley performing at the Fort Homer Hesterly Armory in Tampa, Florida, on July 31, 1955. Presley was a support act for Andy Griffith that night and was yet to reach the national charts, but that didn’t keep him from rocking out.
metadata.pullquote: When the King was a Prince
metadata.summary: A record can be iconic and flawed at the same time. This is unrefined, hit and miss, and sometimes irresistible. I don’t think it should have been any other way.
metadata.blurb: A record can be iconic and flawed at the same time. Elvis' desbut is unrefined, hit and miss, and sometimes irresistible. Could it be any other way?

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Weather // Tycho
metadata.summary: There’s easy listening, and then there’s something like Weather. This is ambient Muzak. For all its smoothness and gentleness it barely leaves any impression at all.
metadata.blurb: This is ambient Muzak. For all its smoothness and gentleness it barely leaves any impression at all.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Disintegration // The Cure
metadata.summary: Creating a distinctive, ethereal sound that feels suitably of its time, there are some cracking moments to be had here. While I do grow weary of it towards the end, there's certainly nothing bad here. An excellent album that's stood the test of time.
metadata.blurb: It’s like Frankenstein in a dinner jacket. Gothic synth rock sounds like a recipe for disaster, but it sounds delicious when The Cure does it.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Anima // Thom Yorke
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by ‘Dr. Tchock’ (i.e. Yorke) and long-time Radiohead collaborator Stanley Donwood. The illustration is in pencil and the font used is Radikal.
essentialtracks: I Am a Very Rude Person
metadata.summary: ANIMA has the hallmark Yorke oddball jumpiness, but there are some really fluid sounds at play too. The production is top notch, and I expect the wanderings are pleasant enough to leave most fans satisfied. Does the album surprise and delight? No, but it does please.
metadata.blurb: ANIMA has the Yorke's classic oddball jumpiness, but there are some really fluid sounds at play too. Does the album delight? No, but it does satisfy.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Ágætis byrjun // Sigur Rós
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Gotti Bernhöft. It is a nod to the album’s name, which translates as ‘a good beginning.’ The original drawing was in ballpoint pen, which was then inverted to produce the final design.
metadata.summary: I'd argue 70 minutes of lush ambient art-rock does actually get tiring when it lacks variety. Layers upon layers of sensuous strings, steady soundscapes, and ghostly vocals combine to create an record that is impressive, yet frustratingly fatiguing.
metadata.blurb: Layers upon layers of sensuous strings, steady soundscapes, and ghostly vocals combine to create an record that is impressive, yet fatiguing.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Gold & Grey // Baroness
metadata.summary: Substandard mixing and monotonous vocals hints at a lack of finesse that restricts Gold & Grey to being a good album rather than a great one. The concept deserves admiration, and the songwriting is satisfying on the whole, but it’s missing the finishing touch.
metadata.blurb: Gold & Grey strives to be an epic of sorts, with its sprawling tracklist and adventurous sonic deviations. Despite some frustrations, it largely succeeds.

author.name: André Dack, Marcus Lawrence & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Real Thing // Faith No More
metadata.summary: In terms of style, substance, and general quality, it's absolutely all over the place. I would guardedly describe it as a journey of funky new wave rap-metal, and if that depiction sounds ridiculous... well that's because it is.
metadata.blurb: Faith No More create a journey of funky new wave rap-metal, and if that depiction sounds ridiculous... well that's because it is.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: ZUU // Denzel Curry
metadata.summary: ZUU is a tour de force in the bait and switch: for every blunt or cliched element across its 30-minute runtime there’s an immediate follow-up that borders on genius. I’d argue that Denzel Curry even crosses that border every so often.
metadata.blurb: The heated, high-tempered attitude that Curry carried on 2018's TA13OO has been replaced by a less hostile outlook. ZUU is a fun ride.

author.name: André Dack, Marcus Lawrence & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Murder the Mountains // Red Fang
metadata.summary: Murder the Mountains might not be trying to something more than face value here, but it doesn’t need to. This album is a solid and grounded rock offering with interesting vocal themes, expansive drums, and raucous riffs.
metadata.blurb: This album is a solid and grounded metal music offering with interesting vocal themes, expansive drums, and raucous riffs. Well worth a try.

author.name: Gabriel Sutton, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: IGOR // Tyler, the Creator
metadata.summary: Tyler deliberately plays against his strengths and manages to push himself to make a good non-rap album. That in itself is pretty fucking fascinating.
metadata.blurb: Tyler plays against his strengths and manages to push himself to make a good non-rap album. That in itself is pretty fucking fascinating.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Anoyo // Tim Hecker
metadata.summary: Tim Hecker is often credited as an ambient producer, but Anoyo is at odds with Eno's quote that defines the genre. There's very little to 'ignore'. To get the most out of the record, listeners must embrace the obscurity and relish the moments of discomfort; probing shadows in order to find answers.
metadata.blurb: To get the most out of the record, listeners must embrace the obscurity and relish the moments of discomfort; probing shadows in order to find answers.

author.name: André Dack, Gabriel Sutton & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Father of the Bride // Vampire Weekend
metadata.summary: The songwriting, performances and production are all top notch. But my word is it sterile. The majority of these songs wouldn't feel out of place in an advert for Google, such is the clinical nature of their formation.
metadata.blurb: Catchy and sterile. The majority of these songs wouldn't feel out of place in an advert for Google, such is the clinical nature of their formation.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Let Love In // Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds
tags: nick cave and the bad seeds
metadata.summary: The arrangements are expansive and diverse, with coarse guitars blending between the lines of timpani, bells, piano, and organ. Lots of organ. The Bad Seeds set a perfect scene for Cave's poignant poetry.
metadata.blurb: The arrangements are expansive and diverse, with coarse guitars blending between the lines of timpani, bells, piano, and organ. Lots of organ.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Gabriel Sutton

metadata.title: The Stone Roses // The Stone Roses
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by band guitarist John Squire. It was inspired by the Paris riots of May 1968, in which students and workers protested capitalism, consumerism, and other scourges of civilisation. The lemons in the artwork refer to the fruit's usage as a tear gas antidote during the protests.
metadata.summary: Though clearly a product of the ‘80s the album wears its age with grace. It’s a broody, elegant, sometimes transcendent blend of rock and electronic music quite unlike anything made before or since, even by The Stone Roses.
metadata.blurb: A broody, elegant, sometimes transcendent blend of rock and electronic music unlike anything made before or since, even by The Stone Roses.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Ventura // Anderson .Paak
metadata.summary: A bit of raucousness would be nice, a bit of grit. Ventura is nothing if not steady. It makes for a super consistent hip hop experience, but I can’t help but wonder what might have been achieved with the safety wheels off.
metadata.blurb: Ventura is super consistent hip hop experience, but we can’t help but wonder what might have been achieved with the safety wheels off.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Titanic Rising // Weyes Blood
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by Australian photographer Brett Stanley. Blood saw the bedroom as an expression of modern individualism. ‘It’s kind of like the waters have risen over this bedroom which to me is symbolic of kind of a subconscious altar that all young people in western culture create for themselves,’ she said.
metadata.summary: Titanic Rising goes above and beyond to attempt something extraordinary, and even if it doesn’t quite reach those desired heights, Weyes Blood deserves serious commendation.
metadata.blurb: Despite its glistening arrangements and ethereal production, this is a cheesy, yet excellently realised, pop album at heart; bold and forthright.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Strange Creatures // Drenge
favouritetracks: When I Look into Your Eyes
metadata.summary: Strange Creatures is a solid entry into the band's catalogue and certainly worth a listen. As to whether it'll stick around until the end of the year? I'm a lot less sure.
metadata.blurb: A solid entry into the band's catalogue and certainly worth a listen. As to whether it'll stick around until the end of the year? I'm a lot less sure.

author.name: Gabriel Sutton, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: LP5 // Apparat
metadata.summary: LP5 seems comfortable not pushing any boundaries. Tracks unravel steadily, with heavy attention shown towards atmosphere and production (both of which are the album's strong points). Rarely are there any momentous changes to melodic composition, such is the ambient nature of the work.
metadata.blurb: LP5 seems comfortable not pushing any boundaries. Tracks unravel steadily, with heavy attention shown towards atmosphere and production.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Two Suns // Bat for Lashes
metadata.artworkCredit: was a collaboration between Natasha Kahn and graphic designer Andrew Murabito, with photography by David Benjamin Sherry. The contrasting front and back images were intended to echo the two personalities storylined within the albums tracks.
metadata.summary: While much of the tracklist doesn't feel as though it explores its ideas far enough, its highlights go a long way to make up for it. It's easy to see why some regard this as Khan's best work, but it isn't without its missteps.
metadata.blurb: While much of the Two Sun's tracklist doesn't feel as though it explores its ideas far enough, its highlights go a long way to make up for it.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost – Part 1 // Foals
metadata.album: Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost – Part 1
metadata.summary: Foals’ experimentation with synths and funky instrumentals is bold, often promising, but the pieces never quite fall together. This listens like (part one of) an ambitious project that gets away from itself. Disparate elements are pulled together lovingly, but certainly not seamlessly.
metadata.blurb: Foals’ experimentation with synths and funky instrumentals is bold, often promising, but the pieces never quite fall together.

author.name: Gabriel Sutton, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: When I Get Home // Solange
metadata.summary: When I Get Home, unfortunately, feels like neither a continuation nor progression from its predecessor. The weightlessness of Solange’s delivery feels less the result of the near-angelic demeanour with which she sang on A Seat at the Table, and more that of sheer emptiness.
metadata.blurb: When I Get Home feels like neither a continuation nor progression from its predecessor. Here Solange’s airy delivery is empty rather than angelic.

author.name: André Dack, Marcus Lawrence & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Crushing // Julia Jacklin
metadata.summary: In a time where singer-songwriters are ten a penny, Julia Jacklin has created an album that stands out from the crowd. It doesn't reach heady heights or make grand proclamations, but it's made for a wonderful listen.
metadata.blurb: In a time where singer-songwriters are ten a penny, Julia Jacklin has created an album that stands out from the crowd. She's one to watch.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The College Dropout // Kanye West
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Eric Duvauchelle. The lavish frame around the main Dropout Bear photograph was taken from a book of 16th century illustrations. ‘The gold ornaments [...] represented the admiration Kanye has for art,’ Duvauchelle said, ‘and he wanted to drastically depart from the typical image of rap at the time—to bring a sense of elegance and style to what was typically a gangster-led image of rap artists.’
metadata.summary: A defiant record. Turning its back not only on the college path, but the tropes of gangster rap as well, The College Dropout dares to be different in weird, supremely catchy ways. The record is more measured than his later work, but there’s still plenty of nuttiness.
metadata.blurb: Turning its back not only on the college path, but tropes of gangster rap as well, The College Dropout dares to be different in weird, supremely catchy ways.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Vol. 4 :: Slaves of Fear // HEALTH
metadata.summary: HEALTH have continued their trend of making exhilarating music, but something feels slightly off this time round. The departure of founding member Jupiter Keyes has likely played a major part, though its Jacob Duzsik's faint whines that proves to be the most underwhelming aspect.
metadata.blurb: HEALTH have continued their trend of making exhilarating music, but something feels off this time round. A record this polished shouldn't feel so flat.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Things Fall Apart // The Roots
metadata.artworkCredit: came in five versions during its original run, each with a different photograph capturing ‘visual failure in society.’ The image your see here, and which became the ‘default’ option, was taken in the 1960s during a riot in the Bedford–Stuyvesant neighbourhood of Brooklyn. Art director Kenny Gravillis said, ‘The cover felt like the urban community could really relate to it. Seeing real fear in the woman’s face is very affecting. It feels unflinching and aggressive in its commentary on society.’
metadata.summary: Given the melancholic tone, it's amazing just how easy and enjoyable it is to listen to. Things Fall Apart is a fluid, continuous listen; understated to the point of being an excellent backdrop, which is both a blessing and a curse.
metadata.blurb: Things Fall Apart is a fluid, continuous listen: understated to the point of being an excellent backdrop, which is both a blessing and a curse.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Specials // The Specials
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photo taken by Welsh photographer Chalkie Davies at the Canal Basin in Coventry, the band’s home town. The members were cut out with a pair of scissors at the request of keyboard player Jerry Dammers, who wanted it ‘to look cheesy.’ The cutout was then incorporated into the iconic black and white ‘anti-design’ of 2 Tone Records.
metadata.summary: There is plenty of anger in The Specials, but it is used in service of its songwriting. At a time when much music seemed obsessed with rejection, The Specials were bold enough — and talented enough — to provide affirmation.
metadata.blurb: There is plenty of anger in the album, but it is used constructively. At a time when much music was obsessed with rejection, The Specials gave affirmation.

author.name: Marcus Lawrence, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Assume Form // James Blake
metadata.artworkCredit: features a shot by American photographer Amanda Charchian, with styling by Rita Zebdi and grooming by Christine Nelli. How they convinced Blake to pull back the fringe we’ll never know.
metadata.summary: Blake's words are far more direct than ever before, and it suits the more focused nature of his songwriting, particularly in the album's second half. Blake has always been excellent at setting a mood, but for the first time in his career he actually exudes genuine emotive qualities.
metadata.blurb: Blake has always been hugely successful at setting a mood, but for the first time in his career he actually exudes genuine emotive qualities.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Hunky Dory // David Bowie
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph of Bowie taken by Brian Ward, with colouring by Terry Pastor. It was inspired by a Marlene Dietrich photo book Bowie took to the photo shoot.
metadata.summary: The songwriting is unbelievably good, to the point where it sounds effortless. Bowie, fresh from having his first child, shows sensitivity, humour, and even a little arrogance. In many ways, it was the sign of things to come.
metadata.blurb: The songwriting is unbelievably good, to the point where it sounds effortless. Bowie shows sensitivity, humour, and even a little arrogance.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Let It Bleed // The Rolling Stones
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American graphic designer Robert Brownjohn. Keith Richards hired Brownjohn, who in turned hired English cook Delia Smith to bake the cake that sat atop the ‘record stack.’ The back cover shows the same stack in total disarray.
metadata.pullquote: A glimpse of the Swinging Sixties
metadata.summary: Blues, psychedelia, jazz, and gospel are all deeply ingrained in at least some part of Let It Bleed, and while this is still a rock record, the key to its success is the wide influences that give each track a flavour of its own.
metadata.blurb: Blues, psychedelia, jazz, and gospel are all deeply ingrained in the music. This is a rock record, but every track has a flavour of its own.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Toxicity // System of a Down
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Mark Wakefield, one of the band’s founding members.
metadata.summary: It may not be the best in its class, but Toxicity still has a charm to it. With several stand-out tracks and variations that set it apart from the pack, the record is a worthwhile listen for a turn of the century flavour of metal.
metadata.blurb: It may not be the best in its class, but Toxicity still has a charm to it. The record is a worthwhile listen for turn of the century flavour metal.

author.name: André Dack, Gabriel Sutton & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Midnight Marauders // A Tribe Called Quest
metadata.summary: An exhibition of seemingly boundless creativity, each track distinct, original, and memorable. Despite the liveliness, the album has a consistent thread of lounge-esque chill throughout — sit back and relax, you’re in the best of hands.
metadata.blurb: Midnight Marauders’ tracklist is an exhibition of seemingly boundless creativity, each track distinct, original, and memorable.

author.name: Marcus Lawrence, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: FM! // Vince Staples
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Japanese artist Verdy.
metadata.summary: There’s an audacity to the concept that’s hard to ignore. FM! really does sound like a cartoonish snippet of overblown California radio, with all the pomp and sunshine and shadow that entails.
metadata.blurb: An audacious project, FM! sounds like a cartoonish snippet of overblown California radio, with all the pomp and sunshine and shadow that entails.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Honey // Robyn
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by German photographer Heji Shin, with a custom typeface designed by French graphic designer Laura Jouan.
metadata.summary: From the lush, low-key title track to the gentle pleading of “Baby Forgive Me”, Honey delights in a downtempo sensuality. It finds voice in not being larger than life, delving instead into the deeply personal.
metadata.blurb: Honey delights in a downtempo sensuality. It finds voice in not being larger than life, delving instead into the deeply personal.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Broken Politics // Neneh Cherry
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by German photographer Wolfgang Tillman.
metadata.summary: Broken Politics projects a great deal of wisdom with tremendous humility and sincerity. It's a low-key listen that will resonate with some, whilst leaving others slightly underwhelmed.
metadata.blurb: For every moment of serenity there's a feeling of incompleteness, and the result is an album that's sadly unmemorable.

metadata.title: Bottle It In // Kurt Vile
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Vile himself. ‘I basically found an old record that I liked and had it morphed and used the wear of that record,’ he said. ‘I wanted it to look used and worn in. I always think things look a little strange, when they’re super crisp and modern.’
metadata.summary: The whole record has an easiness of manner, content to be the sonic backdrop for a wanderer with no particular destination in mind. The mix colours all this perfectly. Vile's explorations deserve an expansive setting, and they get one.
metadata.blurb: The whole record has an easiness of manner, content to be the sonic backdrop for a wanderer with no particular destination in mind.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Queens of the Stone Age // Queens of the Stone Age
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph taken from Mark Gabor’s 1972 book ‘The Pin-Up: A Modest History’. The image first came to the band’s attention through a postcard bought by frontman Josh Homme in Amsterdam in 1993.
metadata.summary: In a lot of ways I love this album. But stood in a row with its successors I can’t help but see it as inferior for the lack of arrogant boundary warping, or the self-assured, unrepentant coolness with which every other album has been delivered.
metadata.blurb: QOTSA’s debut serves as a glimpse into their career as princesses, before being made queens. There's always time for good ol’ sleazy rock’n’roll.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Marcus Lawrence

metadata.title: Daydream Nation // Sonic Youth
metadata.artworkCredit: features a 1983 painting called “Candle” by avant-garde German artist Gerhard Richter.
metadata.summary: From the unravelled instrumentals to the tongue-in-cheek packaging, it’s a kind of anti-epic; 70 minutes of exploratory rock with a flagrant disregard for pacing or commercial viability.
metadata.blurb: Noisy and arty, the album remains a kind of anti-epic; 70 minutes of exploratory rock with a flagrant disregard for pacing or commercial viability.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: >>> // BEAK>
metadata.artworkCredit: was a collaboration between artist Marc Bessant, graphic designer 45rpmWHAT, and God. So said Geoff Barrow, who would know.
metadata.pullquote: Unkempt, kooky, and completely at ease
metadata.summary: The record feels intentionally eroded: instrumentals strike upon funky yet claustrophobic grooves, awaiting Barrow’s vocals to emerge from the mire. It’s a weird but often wonderful formula.
metadata.blurb: Instrumentals strike upon funky-yet-claustrophobic grooves, awaiting Barrow’s vocals to emerge from the mire. It’s a weird but often wonderful formula.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Double Negative // Low
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by British artist Peter Liversidge.
favouritetracks: Always Trying to Work It Out
metadata.summary: There’s a constant stream of static with blunt edges, and the glitches are rarely more than a few moments apart, but it doesn’t come off as overbearing. It’s soothing, and occasionally cathartic when the smudged out instrumentation reaches a crescendo.
metadata.blurb: A constant stream of static with blunt edges, and the glitches are rarely more than a few moments apart, but it doesn’t come off as overbearing.

author.name: Marcus Lawrence, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: And Nothing Hurt // Spiritualized
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by British artist Mark Farrow.
favouritetracks: Here it Comes (The Road) Let’s Go
metadata.summary: This is the first Spiritualized album in six years, so I’m left wondering why it feels like the product of artistic saturation. It’s certainly cohesive, and there are some gorgeous moments, but it ultimately winds up being forgettable.
metadata.blurb: This is the first Spiritualized album in six years, so it's bizarre to hear something that sounds like the product of artistic saturation.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Joy as an Act of Resistance // IDLES
metadata.album: Joy as an Act of Resistance
favouritetracks: Never Fight a Man With a Perm
metadata.summary: Refreshingly sincere and positive in a time where artists are finding it easy to sensationalise and despair. Its instrumentals are tetchy and fast-paced as one might expect of punk rock, but they retain a weight that often gets lost in the blasts of drums and guitars synonymous with the genre.
metadata.blurb: Joy as an Act of Resistance is refreshingly sincere and positive in a time where artists are finding it easy to sensationalise and despair.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Antidotes // Foals
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by British artist Christopher Wright, aka Tinhead. The original artwork he submitted had two people on it - a man and a woman - but band frontman Yannis Philippakis thought cutting it down to one would make the cover more iconic. ‘We had an argument,’ Wright said, ‘but in the end, obviously, he got his way.’
metadata.summary: Foals leaned into their restless, agitated, math-rock roots and carved out a niche in the mainstream indie rock of the time. The result is an album that has a distinctive, angsty vibe throughout, from the initial competing horns of the opener to the minor twinkling of the closer’s end.
metadata.blurb: Foals leaned into their restless, agitated, math-rock roots and carved out a niche in the mainstream indie rock of the time.

author.name: Gabriel Sutton, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Smote Reverser // Oh Sees
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American artist Matt Stawicki. John Dwyer had always wanted to work with an artist with a pulp science fiction background. ‘It was two different worlds coming together,’ Dwyer said.
metadata.summary: If you can tap into Oh Sees’ frequency there’s no reason why this can’t be a lovely hour in the haze. The record needs that buy-in, though. Without it I find it hard to escape the feeling the band are getting a lot more out of all this than I am.
