metadata.summary: Homme’s quip that rock 'should be heavy enough for the boys and sweet enough for the girls' rings true here; there’s a near perfect balance of grit and finesse on ...Like Clockwork that surely makes it Queens of the Stone Age’s most accomplished work since Songs for the Deaf.
metadata.blurb: Homme’s quip that rock 'should be heavy enough for the boys and sweet enough for the girls' rings true here; there’s a near perfect balance of grit and finesse.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: 25 // Adele
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by British photographer Alasdair McLellan. It is of Adele’s face.
favouritetracks: Send My Love (To Your New Lover)
metadata.summary: Adele has proven she has the vocal and songwriting talent to do more than release a pop record with songs filled with heartbreak, yet will probably never explore these possibilities further while albums like 25 sell faster than anything that has come before it.
metadata.blurb: Inoffensive and unspectacular pop fodder. People will listen to it on the radio and find it agreeable and vaguely evocative and then forget it ever existed.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Overgrown // James Blake
metadata.summary: It’s beautifully discreet, formed with an elegance that virtually pushes it to the point of invisibility — blissful for some, but perhaps too despondent for others. Tracks often linger in a cold ambiance, and if you’re not into what Blake is doing here, the passive nature of the songwriting will likely turn you away.
metadata.blurb: It’s beautifully discreet, formed with an elegance that pushes it to the point of invisibility — blissful for some, but perhaps too despondent for others.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Garden of Delete // Oneohtrix Point Never
metadata.summary: Twisting and turning and purposely blindsiding its listener, Garden of Delete doesn’t stop evolving, and without conforming to any one kind of structure it can at times feel like a stream of consciousness immortalised in music. A single listen simply won’t be enough to take it all in.
metadata.blurb: Twisting and turning and purposely blindsiding its listeners, Garden of Delete doesn’t stop evolving, often feeling like a stream of consciousness in musical form.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: St. Vincent // St. Vincent
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by Russian photographer Renata Raksha.
metadata.summary: A confident release that sparkles with peculiarity but steers away from pretension. In capturing the middle ground between passion and precision, Annie Clark achieves a distinct sound that can only be described as some sort of melodic computer malfunction.
metadata.blurb: Capturing the middle ground between passion and precision, Annie Clark’s sound here can only be described as some sort of melodic computer malfunction.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Divers // Joanna Newsom
metadata.artworkCredit: features a photograph taken by American artist Kim Keever.
metadata.summary: Beautifully crafted in its arrangement and narrative, Joanna Newsom creates a World on Divers that is both wonderful and despairing. Music of such dainty character will inevitably turn certain audiences away, which is a shame because frankly, Divers is a triumph.
metadata.blurb: A world both wonderful and despairing. Such dainty music will inevitably turn certain audiences away, which is a shame because, frankly, Divers is a triumph.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: 18 // Moby
favouritetracks: We Are All Made of Stars
metadata.summary: Strung together with down tempo drum beats, silky basslines, warming pads, and soulful vocals, it’s certainly a very consumable album, with little to jolt a listener’s senses. This, I feel, is the downfall of 18.
metadata.blurb: Strung together with downtempo drum beats, silky basslines, warming pads, and soulful vocals, it’s a very consumable album with little to jolt listeners' senses.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Sexwitch // Sexwitch
metadata.summary: With its contagious aura of revelry and high sense of spirituality, Natasha Khan’s latest project initially proves quite alluring. Impressive vocal performances and a rhythm section that proves immensely gratifying in its tribal nature ensure Sexwitch makes for an enjoyable — if limited — experience.
metadata.blurb: Impressive vocal performances and a hugely gratifying tribal rhythm section ensure *Sexwitch* makes for an enjoyable — if limited — experience.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: First Impressions of Earth // The Strokes
metadata.artworkCredit: features a 1968 painting by German avant-garde artist Lothar Quinte. The painting’s name is “Ohne Titel”, or “Untitled”.
metadata.summary: First Impressions of Earth is a model misunderstood album; flawed, overdrawn, deserving of a good deal of its harsh reviews, and yet still host to a unique and worthwhile character. It is tremendously raw, a pained scrawl.
metadata.blurb: A model misunderstood album; flawed, overdrawn, deserving of a good deal of its harsh reviews, and yet still host to a unique and worthwhile character.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Compton // Dr. Dre
metadata.summary: A polished, lumbering beast of an album. Not so much concerned with peaks and troughs as with a steady, charismatic drone of all things Compton. Dr. Dre’s latest concoction rides a peculiar line between celebration and reflection.
metadata.blurb: A polished, lumbering beast of an album. Not so much concerned with peaks and troughs as with a steady, charismatic drone of all things Compton.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: 9 // Public Image Ltd
metadata.summary: It isn’t a classic, it isn’t conventional, it’s oftentimes a bit daft, but it does what it does terribly well. 9 is a loud and peppy splash of creativity, and sometimes that’s all an album needs to be.
metadata.blurb: It isn’t a classic, it isn’t conventional, it’s oftentimes a bit daft, but the record does what it does terribly well. A loud and peppy splash of creativity.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Blood // Lianne La Havas
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by Philippines-born photographer John-Paul Pietrus.
metadata.summary: For all the merits of Lianne La Havas’s thoroughly lovely and dynamic voice, the album ultimately comes across as lopsided and a little flat. This isn’t to say Blood isn’t a pleasant listen — it is — but it could have been so much more.
metadata.blurb: For all the merits of Lianne La Havas’s thoroughly lovely and dynamic voice, the album ultimately comes across as lopsided and a little flat.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Low // David Bowie
metadata.summary: Between the delicious bite-sized servings of vintage Bowie glam-rock and the brooding beauty of the instrumental pieces, Low is a model two-sided album; something that adapts the format and twists it to its own ends. What results is a delicate and insightful balance of showmanship and reflection.
metadata.blurb: Bite-sized servings of vintage Bowie glam-rock combine with brooding instrumental soundscapes to make Low a truly special album.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: My Love Is Cool // Wolf Alice
metadata.summary: Wolf Alice have clearly experimented with plenty of good ideas in the first half of this decade, but I have a feeling once they find their sound and concentrate their efforts on that, they will be a band to watch throughout the second half.
metadata.blurb: A record that’s unabashed and vibrant and full of potential. Wolf Alice show glimpses of what's to come, straddling genres with almost childlike enthusiasm.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Exodus // Bob Marley and The Wailers
metadata.summary: It has moments of quite profound Marley charm, but such peaks are matched by (very pleasant) plateaus. When I listen to Exodus I don't hear a great album; I hear a good album with a handful of iconic songs.
metadata.blurb: Peaks are matched by (very pleasant) plateaus. Exodus isn't so much a great album as it is a good album with a handful of iconic songs.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Starfire // Jaga Jazzist
metadata.summary: A model of casual listening. It bustles along quite happily, from section to section, from track to track, and then it's over and you don't regret having listened to it.
metadata.blurb: A model of casual listening. It bustles along quite happily, from section to section, from track to track, and then it's over and you don't regret having listened to it.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: On the Beach // Neil Young
metadata.artworkCredit: was a collaboration between Gary Burden (design), Bob Seideman (photography), and Rick Griffin (lettering). The 1959 Cadillac tailfin was from a Santa Ana junkyard, Young’s outfit was bought in a ‘sleazy men’s shop’, the newspaper was picked up in LA, and the patio set came from a run-of-the-mill patio supply store (this was the ’70s remember. The cover was shot at Santa Monica beach, and Burden said it was the favourite he ever made.
metadata.summary: Perfect for those late nights alone, where the further you venture into the album, the more poignant the evening feels. Both mellow and despondent, the record features the purest of songwriting from a genuine artist.
metadata.blurb: On The Beach is perfect for those late nights alone. Both mellow and despondent, the record features the purest of songwriting from a genuine artist.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Drones // Muse
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American illustrator Matthew S. Mahurin. ‘People refer to “drones” as those flying machines and robots but a drone can be anything,’ he said. ‘A student, a soldier… anything that’s subject to being controlled and manipulated.’
metadata.summary: The opening third is nothing to write home about, the middle section is terrific, and the last twenty minutes dismantles world tyranny by channelling Grease, Les Mis, bad Pink Floyd, and the singing turrets in Portal 2.
metadata.blurb: The opening third is nothing to write home about, the middle section is terrific, and the last twenty minutes are ludicrous. Drones is the full Muse package.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Origin of Symmetry // Muse
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by illustrator William Eager.
metadata.summary: It’s breathless, explosive music; the kind that compels listeners to pick up an instrument or start a band. Origin of Symmetry listens like a spectacular jam — with all the unpolished, patchy, brazen energy that entails — and all in all it’s pretty rad, man.
metadata.blurb: There are few better highs than Muse in top gear. It’s breathless, explosive music; the kind that compels listeners to pick up an instrument or start a band.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Jackrabbit // San Fermin
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by American artist Stephen Halker using pencil and digital painting. ‘I wanted to create a certain amount of dissonance in the rabbit to go along with the structure of the songs,’ he said. ‘Under the superficial layer of dirt and fur, there’s a hidden core of gold. Under the blanket of the mundane, the world is filled with immeasurable wealth.’
metadata.summary: Whilst it's carefully constructed, flowing beautifully from beginning to end, the album in its entirety can feel slightly taxing due to the bloated, overstuffed nature of the songwriting.
metadata.blurb: Flowing beautifully from beginning to end, the album in its entirety can feel slightly taxing due to the bloated, overstuffed nature of the songwriting.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Revolver // The Beatles
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by German artist Klaus Voormann. The line drawing style was inspired by English illustrator Aubrey Beardsley, and combined with a collage of photos mostly taken by Robert Freeman. The Beatles’ manager, Brian Epstein, wept when he saw the finished cover because it suited the music so well.
metadata.summary: Full to the brim with ideas that are executed with such precision, skillfully mixed with care and delicacy, resulting in a complete work that seems somehow effortless in its construction.
metadata.blurb: One of the most enjoyable pop albums of all time, an iconic work that will forever be used as an example for songwriting expertise.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Magic Whip // Blur
metadata.summary: The Magic Whip is a rather unbalanced comeback — a tired album that relies too heavily on its somber tone, resulting in forgettable and lifeless songs that drift by in apathetic fashion.
metadata.blurb: A rather unbalanced comeback that relies too heavily on its somber tone, resulting in forgettable and lifeless songs that drift by in apathetic fashion.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Demon Days // Gorillaz
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by English comic book artist Jamie Hewlett, who was co-founded the band with Damon Albarn.
favouritetracks: Fire Coming Out of the Monkey's Head
metadata.summary: A cartoonish odyssey bristling with creative energy. The whimsy of the band's debut album is toned down, and what emerges in its stead is a biting sombreness very much of the 21st century. It's eclectic in the very best sense of the word.
metadata.blurb: A cartoonish odyssey bristling with creative energy. The whimsy of the band's debut album is replaced by a biting sombreness very much of the 21st century.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Damogen Furies // Squarepusher
metadata.summary: Squarepusher produces another solid album without pushing any boundaries or venturing into unfamiliar territory. The beats are as intricate as ever, whilst the melodies, as sporadic as they are, retain the classic Squarepusher charm.
metadata.blurb: Squarepusher produces another solid album without pushing any boundaries. The beats are as intricate as ever, whilst the melodies keep their charm.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Joshua Tree // U2
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by Dutch photographer Anton Corbijn, with the overall design orchestrated by Irish graphic artist Steve Averill. ‘What I was trying to do with the way we shot the pictures and framed the cover was to suggest the landscape vision and cinematic approach that was taken to the recording,’ Averill said.
metadata.summary: U2 achieved a vast and powerful sound that crucially stopped itself from treading into the territory of the overly bombastic; here we experience the band without the excruciating self-indulgence that turns listeners away from their more recent works.
metadata.blurb: With a vast and powerful sound, here we experience U2 without the excruciating self-indulgence that turns listeners away from their more recent works.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Powers that B // Death Grips
metadata.summary: As with a lot of Death Grips' output, a great deal of The Powers That B seems like it shouldn't work. It's just a huge, crazy wall of sound, and that makes for an exhausting listen; yet it works well despite it all.
metadata.blurb: A lot of The Power That B seems like it shouldn't work, and yet it does. It's a huge, crazy wall of sound, and that makes for an exhausting listen.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Power, Corruption & Lies // New Order
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by British graphic artist Peter Saville. It features a reproduction of “A Basket of Roses”, a painting by French artist Henri Fantin-Latour. Saville came across the image on a postcard in the National Gallery gift shop. ‘Flowers suggested the means by which power, corruption and lies infiltrate our lives,’ he said. ‘They’re seductive.’
metadata.summary: New Order's significance is admirable, no question, but in the present day the core of their music feels regrettably lifeless. With this release, the catchy riffs and toe-tapping beats are there, but that's precisely the problem - stubborn in nature, with very little desire to change, they are just there.
metadata.blurb: The catchy riffs and toe-tapping beats are there, but that's precisely the problem - stubborn in nature, with very little desire to change, they are just there.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: To Pimp a Butterfly // Kendrick Lamar
metadata.artworkCredit: was shot by French photographer Denis Rouvre under the direction of Lamar, Dave Free, and Vlad Sepetov. Most of those pictured are family members or friends of Lamar, who said the cover was ‘taking a group of the homies who haven’t seen the world and putting them in these places that they haven’t necessarily seen, or only on TV and showing them something different other than the neighbourhood and them being excited about it. That’s why they have them wild faces on there.’
metadata.summary: If Good Kid, M.A.A.D City introduced Kendrick Lamar to the masses, To Pimp A Butterfly cements his place in the hip-hop hall of fame. This is an instant classic.
metadata.blurb: If Good Kid, M.A.A.D City introduced Kendrick Lamar to the masses, To Pimp A Butterfly cements his place in the hip hop hall of fame. This is an instant classic.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Rain Dogs // Tom Waits
metadata.artworkCredit: features a shot taken by Swedish photographer Anders Petersen in the late 1960s. Then a student, Petersen frequented a dive bar called Cafe Lehmitz near Hamburg’s red-light district, taking photographs of its regulars and travelling back to Stockholm to process the film. The man and woman pictured on the artwork are Rose and Lilly. Petersen said many men were in love with Lilly, and she knew it.
metadata.summary: It’s down, dirty, and very, very human; an album that gets under your skin and taps your toes for you. Rain Dogs isn’t for everyone, but if you want to hear what the roots of an urban jungle sound like - in all their sad and messy madness - it’s well worth a listen.
metadata.blurb: Rain Dogs isn’t for everyone, but if you want to hear what the roots of an urban jungle sound like - in all their sad and messy madness - it’s well worth a listen.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Downward Spiral // Nine Inch Nails
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by British collagist Russell Mills, with Trent Reznor asking for art that evoked ‘attrition’ and ‘decay.’ Mills went so far as to use his own blood while making the piece. Talk about commitment.
metadata.summary: Reznor set a benchmark in the industrial rock genre whilst simultaneously providing a form of therapy for millions of angst-filled listeners, who inevitably soaked up his devastating portrayal of nihilism.
metadata.blurb: Trent Reznor set a benchmark in the industrial rock genre whilst simultaneously providing a form of therapy for millions of angst-filled listeners.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: The Dark Side of the Moon // Pink Floyd
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by English graphic artist Storm Thorgerson. ‘It related mostly to a light show,’ he said. ‘They hadn’t really celebrated their light show. That was one thing. The other thing was the triangle. I think the triangle, which is a symbol of thought and ambition, was very much a subject of Roger’s lyrics.’
metadata.album: The Dark Side of the Moon
metadata.summary: The Dark Side of the Moon is one of those high-water marks of artistic expression. It's just sublime. I don't have a bad thing to say about it.
metadata.blurb: The Dark Side of the Moon is one of those high-water marks of artistic expression. It’s just sublime. I don’t have a bad thing to say about it.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Arthur (Or the Decline and Fall of the British Empire) // The Kinks
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Australian artist Bob Lawrie.
metadata.album: Arthur (Or the Decline and Fall of the British Empire)
metadata.summary: A good deal of the songs are beautiful in ways only Ray Davies can achieve, but the album’s scattered feel keeps it from being more than the sum of its parts.
metadata.blurb: The songs are beautiful in ways only Ray Davies can achieve, but the album’s scattered feel keeps it from being more than the sum of its parts.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Ladies and Gentleman We Are Floating in Space // Spiritualized
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by Mark Farrow. Its sterile, minimal aesthetic was made to resemble the packaging of prescription medicine. A 2009 edition of the album went so far as to package the songs in an enormous pill box, each song stored on a three-inch CD in an oversized blister pack.
metadata.album: Ladies and Gentleman We Are Floating in Space
favouritetracks: Ladies and Gentlemen We Are Floating in Space
metadata.summary: Tortured themes, fragile vocals, irresistibly groovy basslines, beautifully spacious production, and such a curious closer. Ladies and Gentlemen We Are Floating in Space has numerous key components.
metadata.blurb: A magnificent journey, with tortured themes, fragile vocals, irresistibly groovy basslines, beautifully spacious production, and such a curious closer.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Dig Your Own Hole // The Chemical Brothers
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by design agency Negativespace, which also designed the duo’s logo. Negativespace co-founder Anthony Sweeney said the trippy, quasi-psychedelic logo was on the ‘crazy’ end of the spectrum of ideas they came up with, calling it the ‘antithesis of what we thought of as good typography at the time.’
metadata.summary: Once the more textured songs rear their heads the whole album falls together a little better. The last few tracks are top notch.
metadata.blurb: The Chemical Brothers’ second album is likely to please a number of electric tastes. It seldom rises above a good beat, but then it doesn’t need to.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge

metadata.title: Bossanova // Pixies
metadata.artworkCredit: was designed by British graphic designers Vaughan Oliver and Chris Bigg, and features photography by Simon Larbalestier. Oliver produced the artwork for the band’s entire discography during his lifetime.
metadata.summary: Without the raw energy of Surfer Rosa and cohesiveness of Doolittle, Bossanova is simply a solid album from a remarkable band.
metadata.blurb: Our first ever review. Reads like it too. In any case, the album can certainly boast a groove, but it lacks the edge of Pixies' best work.

author.name: André Dack, Frederick O'Brien & Andrew Bridge
